**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 & 8**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 & 8**, because the underlying events occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court and Defendant resides within the same.

**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: The Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19**, as this is a civil action for damages within the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

**Newton Revised Ordinances \u00a7\u00a7.proposition: Prominent signage in the park clearly stated that all dogs must be kept on leashes while in the park, in accordance with **Newton Revised Ordinances §§ 12-31 and 12-35**, and consistent with **G.L. c. 140, § 173**, which authorizes municipal leash control.

**G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 140, § 173**, and municipal leash ordinances, Defendant had a duty to maintain control of his dog and to keep it restrained by a leash while on public park property.

**Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all persons owe a general duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others. **Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000)**; **Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**.
**Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio does not discuss or articulate a general duty of all persons to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others. Its negligence analysis focuses on the elements of negligence—particularly causation—and expressly declines to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care, noting that the case can be resolved on causation grounds. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the broad, general-duty proposition stated.
**Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them…”

**Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all persons owe a general duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others. **Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000)**; **Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**.
**Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**.support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general negligence principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability. That is precisely the broad duty proposition for which the case is cited, even though the opinion then applies that general rule to the specific context of firearm storage and a violent third party. Thus, Jupin is proper authority for the existence of a general duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm under Massachusetts law.
**Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

**Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929.proposition: The owner or keeper of a dog owes a duty to take reasonable precautions to prevent the animal from causing injury to others. **Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929)**; **Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (1932)**.
**Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory strict liability of an owner or keeper under G.L. c. 140, § 155 and deals with pleading and proof of ‘owner’ versus ‘keeper.’ It does not discuss any common-law duty of reasonable care or reasonable precautions to prevent injury by a dog. The case therefore does not establish or affirm a duty of reasonable care; it simply applies the statutory rule that an owner or keeper is liable when those status elements are proved.
**Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929.relevant_excerpt: G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: “The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.” … Here if Agostino and Rachele jointly were both owners and keepers of the dog, a liability would be established. There was an issue of fact for the jury. The judge, therefore, could not direct a verdict.

**Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (1.proposition: The owner or keeper of a dog owes a duty to take reasonable precautions to prevent the animal from causing injury to others. **Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929)**; **Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (1932)**.
**Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a landlord’s liability for a nuisance (a low-hanging awning) created or maintained by a tenant; it does not involve dogs, animal ownership, or any duty of a dog owner or keeper. The holding focuses on control of premises and the general rule that a landlord is not liable for a nuisance created by a tenant if the premises can be used without becoming a nuisance. Therefore, citing Anderson v. Kopelman for a dog-owner duty of care is inaccurate and out of context.
**Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (1.relevant_excerpt: "It is a general rule that a landlord is not liable to strangers for the consequences to a plaintiff of a nuisance in connection with the building in the possession and control of his tenant, unless the nuisance occasioning the injury existed at the time the premises were demised or the structure was in such condition that it would be likely to become a nuisance in the ordinary and reasonable use of the same. As was said by Sheldon, J., in Coman v. Alles, 198 Mass. 99, 103, '...if the premises can be used by the tenant in the manner intended by the landlord without becoming a nuisance, then the landlord is not liable for any nuisance created by an act of omission or of commission, done by the tenant ... after he has entered into possession.'"}

**Brown v. Boston & Maine R.R., 283 Mass.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that allowing a large dog to run loose in a public jogging area would cause fear, avoidance reactions, and potential injury to nearby parkgoers. **Brown v. Boston & Maine R.R., 283 Mass. 192 (1933)** (foreseeability defines scope of duty).
**Brown v. Boston & Maine R.R., 283 Mass.support_reasoning: The case is about whether a foreign (New Hampshire) administrator qualifies as a “personal representative” with capacity to sue under the Federal Employers’ Liability Act in Massachusetts. It does not discuss foreseeability, scope of duty, or any facts involving animals, fear reactions, or injuries to parkgoers. Citing this case for the foreseeability of harm from a loose dog in a public jogging area misstates its holding and subject matter.
**Brown v. Boston & Maine R.R., 283 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The present action is brought under the Federal employers’ liability act… The words ‘personal representative’ as used in this act… have the meaning ‘executor or administrator’ they being representatives constituted by the proper court… It is settled law that the appointment of an administrator in one State confers no power beyond the limits of that State, and does not authorize him to maintain any suit in the courts, State or national, held in any other State.”

**Stamas v. Fanning, 345 Mass. 73 (1962).proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injury. **Stamas v. Fanning, 345 Mass. 73 (1962)** (causation exists where conduct creates foreseeable risk of the type of harm suffered).
**Stamas v. Fanning, 345 Mass. 73 (1962).support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses proximate cause and reverses a directed verdict, holding that the defendant’s negligent left turn could be found by a jury to be the proximate cause of plaintiffs’ injuries even though plaintiffs’ car was fourth in line. The opinion emphasizes foreseeability—that one who suddenly cuts across a line of traffic without warning can be bound to anticipate damage of the sort sustained—and adopts a “train of events” formulation of proximate cause. This aligns with the proposition that causation exists where the conduct creates a foreseeable risk of the type of harm suffered.
**Stamas v. Fanning, 345 Mass. 73 (1962).relevant_excerpt: “The fact that the Stamas car was the fourth in the eastbound line of traffic did not necessarily make the defendant’s conduct a remote cause. In view of the congested traffic conditions existing today it cannot reasonably be said, as matter of law, that one who cuts across a line of traffic without warning was not bound to anticipate that such conduct would cause damage of the sort sustained by these plaintiffs. In other words, it was open to the jury to find that the negligent act of the defendant set in motion a train of events… and was the proximate cause of it.”

**Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997)*.proposition: The chain of causation was direct and unbroken: Defendant’s negligent supervision caused the dog to charge, Plaintiff reacted in reasonable fear, and she fell, sustaining serious physical injury. **Restatement (Second) of Torts § 284 (1965)**, adopted in **Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997)**.
**Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997)*.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lyon v. Morphew deals with personal liability of hospital employees, scope of duty, and control over an independent contractor, not with a dog attack, negligent supervision of an animal, or a plaintiff’s fear reaction leading to a fall. It does not discuss Restatement (Second) of Torts § 284, causation via a defensive reaction, or an unbroken chain of causation in the manner described in the proposition. The proposition misattributes both the factual scenario and the legal principle to this case.
**Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997)*.relevant_excerpt: “Employees are liable for torts in which they personally participated. See LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 29 (1979); Jet Spray Cooler, Inc. v. Crampton, 377 Mass. 159, 181 (1979). See Restatement (Second) of Agency § 343 (1958). This liability stems from the general rule that every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care for the safety of others. Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). ‘There can be negligence only where there is a duty to be careful.’ Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989) …”

**Carroll v. Bouley, 338 Mass. 625 (1959.proposition: Plaintiff’s reaction to the apparent danger posed by Defendant’s unleashed dog was reasonable under the “emergency doctrine,” which excuses split-second reactions to sudden peril. **Carroll v. Bouley, 338 Mass. 625 (1959)**.
**Carroll v. Bouley, 338 Mass. 625 (1959.support_reasoning: The opinion in Carroll v. Bouley deals with whether a driver who may have suffered a sudden, unforeseeable physical seizure (heart attack) can be found negligent in causing an auto collision. It does not involve a plaintiff’s reaction to an unleashed dog, does not discuss the emergency or sudden peril doctrine as applied to a plaintiff’s split‑second reaction, and contains no facts or reasoning about animals or responses to apparent danger. The proposition misattributes a rule not discussed in this case.
**Carroll v. Bouley, 338 Mass. 625 (1959.relevant_excerpt: "By the great weight of authority a sudden and unforeseeable physical seizure rendering an operator unable to control his motor vehicle cannot be termed negligence... The real issue, upon which the defendant had the burden of proof, is whether the evidence required the jury to find that Bouley was not a responsible operator at the time of entering the intersection."

**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.raw_text: **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)**
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.proposition: Defendant’s violation of the applicable leash law and ordinance constitutes negligence per se. **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)** (statutory violations as evidence of negligence).
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects negligence per se for statutory violations and reiterates the Massachusetts rule that a statutory violation is only some evidence of negligence. The court holds that violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 does not itself establish a breach of duty and that common-law negligence elements must still be proven. Thus, Bennett supports the opposite of the claimed proposition and is being mis-cited if offered for negligence per se; it supports only that statutory violations are evidence of negligence, not conclusive of it.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff seeks full and fair compensation for all injuries and losses proximately resulting from Defendant’s negligence pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, and all applicable law.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: For pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as provided by **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
